channel.title: Retro Games & Linux on NiceTux by Matthew Hungerford
channel.description: Recent content in Retro Games & Linux on NiceTux by Matthew Hungerford

item.title: Nexis/787 UI
item.description: While working at Astronautics, I created the widget toolkit and built the UI for the NEXIS flight system, as well as the previous 787 flight system. For the airport map, which typically had tens of thousands of polygons, in order to get good performance out of the Intel Graphics chip at the time, I created a minimal software renderer that drew on tiles, and uploaded them as textures to be panned.

item.title: Updating Projects
item.description: Many of the sections in the section header are incomplete, I am still catching up on finding pictures and links to old games and projects.

item.title: First Post
item.description: Created this site to archive past games I have written or ported, as well as interesting applications or projects I have worked on.

item.title: Opposite Lock - GP2x Port
item.description: GP2x Port of J2ME Game: Opposite Lock (GPL’d 3d racing game originally coded by Carl Woffenden) OpenHandhelds.org download

item.title: King Of Fighters - Pandora Port
item.description: Pandora Port of Bennu Engine Game: King of Fighters (Fan remake originally coded by Carl Francisco Javier del Pino Cuesta) OpenHandhelds.org download

item.title: Mister Hachi (SHMUP) - GP2x Port
item.description: GP2x Port of J2ME Game: Mister Hachi (SHMUP) (Freeware game originally coded by Carl Francisco Javier del Pino Cuesta)      OpenHandhelds.org download

item.title: Pandas and bananas
item.description: Simple but fun game “Pandas and Bananas” I created for the Pebble Smartwatch. I later worked with Chris Lewis to incorporate the collision code from this game into the PGE (Pebble Game Engine) framework for use by other games. This game includes assets from https://opengameart.org Youtube Gameplay Video

item.title: Skype for PS Vita
item.description: Had a blast while working at Skype. I had the fortune to work with Sony on porting Skype to the PS Vita. Being a fan of games and handhelds, it was exciting having my professional life cross over to gaming for a short while. One of the more interesting things involved in the PS Vita port of Skype was that I had to modify the Skype audio encoding to enable it to use a PS Vita hardware-accelerated audio codec for SILK, the first time that SILK had not been a software encoder for Skype.
